all the teams in both conditions with four-person teams, they had to build a prototype.

all that we asked was, we asked people and said come up with a job title that showcases your unique person on the spot.
So- and it was extraordinary. People came up with titles like guru of cybersecurity,
defender of the source code, chief shmoozer, [LAUGHTER] chief banana, chief instigator.
And we were kind of quite surprised that at the end of the experiment, teams where people chose their own job titles,
they actually built a prototype faster. But most importantly, the prototypes they built, they, at least,
in the eyes of an external panel of judges were measurably superior to the prototype's prepared by the,
uh, other teams under controlled conditions. What? So my sort of speculation is the um- and we actually had evidence of this,
when you ask people to choose their own job titles, the first thing is you're actually triggering a sense of ownership.

was in the teams where people chose their own job titles, it was made clear who should do what.
